intro: Gagea commutata, commonly known as the purple gagea, is a flowering plant species native to the western United States and parts of Canada. It is a member of the Amaryllidaceae family and is characterized by its basal rosette of narrow, grass-like leaves. The plant produces a tall, leafless stem bearing a single, bell-shaped flower with six petals, typically in shades of purple or white. It thrives in woodland and open habitats, often in well-drained soils. Gagea commutata is noted for its early spring blooming period and is considered an ornamental plant in some regions.
